campaign.story:
"The love readers feel for Lucille Clifton—both the woman and her poetry—is constant and deeply felt. The lines that surface most frequently in praise of her work and her person are moving declarations of racial pride, courage, steadfastness." -Toni Morrison
“For me,” Lucille Clifton (1936-2010) said, “poetry is a way of living in the world.” What this beloved author found in poetry is the gift she gives readers: a way of living in the world, of looking at and navigating through the challenges of lived experience. The poems Clifton wrote during her fifty-year career are encapsulations of hope, beauty, courage, and strength.
BOA Editions invites you to join us in celebrating Lucille Clifton’s legacy with the publication of How to Carry Water, a collection of two-hundred of her most poignant poems—ten of which are previously unpublished—selected by award-winning poet Aracelis Girmay.
BOA Editions will publish a hardcover edition of How to Carry Water in fall 2020. Your support will help BOA bring this essential book of one by America’s most prized poets to readers everywhere. 
 the woman who feels everything
sits in her new house
 waiting for someone to come
 who knows how to carry water
 without spilling, who knows
 why the desert is sprinkled
 with salt, why tomorrow
 is such a long and ominous word.
 -Lucille Clifton, from “water sign woman”
Lucille Clifton is the only poet to have two books selected in the same year as finalists for the Pulitzer Prize. Her many accolades include the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, the Robert Frost Medal, the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award, and the National Book Award.
Author Toni Morrison described Clifton’s poetry as “seductive with the simplicity of an atom, which is to say highly complex, explosive underneath an apparent quietude.”
Writing for the New York Times, Reginald Dwayne Betts praised the timeliness—and timelessness—of Clifton’s work: “Clifton’s earliest poems could have been written yesterday, and her later works could have been written decades ago. Each poem is always its own world.”
Poet W.S. Merwin found in Clifton’s work an “abiding joy” in the face of “great loss and trouble, pain and loneliness.”
Lucille Clifton (photo by Rachel Eliza Griffiths Hires)
 “No one writes like Lucille Clifton, and yet, if it were possible to open a voice, like a suitcase, to see what it carries inside it, I believe that inside the voices of many contemporary U.S. American poets are the poems of Lucille Clifton. There is the ferocity of her clear sight. There is the constellatory thinking where every thing is kin.”  -Aracelis Girmay, from the Foreword of How to Carry Water 
Aracelis Girmay, Editor of How to Carry Water, is author of three poetry collections: the black maria (BOA, 2016); Kingdom Animalia (BOA, 2011), winner of the Isabella Gardner Poetry Award and the GLCA New Writers Award, and a finalist for both the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award; and Teeth (Curbstone Press, 2007). The recipient of fellowships from Cave Canem, Civitella Ranieri, and the National Endowment for the Arts, Girmay is the winner of a 2015 Whiting Award for Poetry.  
“It’s hard to overstate how important it was to me to have Aracelis Girmay edit the Lucille Clifton Selected. I trust implicitly in her fierce integrity, discernment, intelligence, and formidable poetic powers — I was literally gleeful at the idea of discovering what she’d select and how she would shape the collection. Her passion for Lucille Clifton’s work is palpable and I knew that Aracelis regarded her as an artistic model, inspiration, and one of America’s best poets. It has been a true pleasure watching Aracelis work on this book and sharing the experience of (as she describes in her Foreword) 'waiting to hear from Ms. Lucille' with another one of America’s best poets.” -BOA Publisher Peter Conners
Aracelis Girmay (photo by Sheila Griffin)
In times of uncertainty, poetry speaks. 
Lucille Clifton's poems are often shared on social media, held up as gems of insight in times of celebration and triumph; in times of struggle and loss. This book of poetry offers Clifton's piercing insight, fierce intelligence, and reassuring humor for devoted fans and new readers alike. An essential collection of poetry, needed now and always. 
 new bones
we will wear
new bones again.
we will leave
these rainy days,
break out through
another mouth
into sun and honey time.
worlds buzz over us like bees,
we be splendid in new bones.
other people think they know
how long life is
how strong life is.
we know.
Lucille Clifton was no stranger to adversity. And yet, her poems manage to address struggle, illness, injustice, and hardship with characteristic JOY. In fact, Joy! was how Clifton inscribed each of her books: it was her wish for her readers. 
 Join us in celebrating Clifton’s legacy. Her spirit. Her poems. Her joy.  
The Lannan Foundation has backed this project with a $40,000 Matching Grant. To date, BOA has raised $19,406 to meet this match—your pledges will get us the rest of the way! To receive any of the funds pledged by our backers, we must raise the full $20,594 by May 8th. As a project backer, you can be one of the first to hold this book in your hands.
REWARDS
To our project backers, we offer our sincere gratitude and an exciting collection of rewards. Backers who pledge $35 or more will receive How to Carry Water in advance of publication. Other rewards include: 
 Early Birds! from the fenceless field, a limited-edition Lucille Clifton chapbook, is available for eight lucky backers during the first week of the campaign. The ten poems in from the fenceless field include reader favorites "why some people be mad at me sometimes" and "won't you celebrate with me." 
 Lucille Clifton: The Documentary. In anticipation of the publication of How to Carry Water, BOA is working with Rochester-based Hunger Media to produce a short documentary film on Lucille Clifton's life and work. All backers at the $50 level and above will receive an early release link to stream the documentary at home! For those who would like to be a special patron of this project, backers at the $5,000 level will be listed in the film's credits.

In 2019, BOA launched Blessing the Boats Selections to highlight the work of women of color poets. Named in honor of Lucille Clifton's National Book Award-winner, this collection of poetry books honors Clifton's legacy and celebrates the present and future work of women of color poets. Backers at the $20 level will receive the first Blessing the Boats Selection, The Year of the Dog by Deborah Paredez. 

 Letterpress broadsides from Expedition Press of Clifton's poems "i am not done yet" and "water sign woman" are available for backers at the $100 and $250 levels.

And more!
ABOUT BOA EDITIONS
BOA Editions is an award-winning independent publisher based in Rochester, NY. The press was founded in 1976 by the late poet, editor, and translator, A. Poulin, Jr. As a pioneering small press, BOA helped shape the landscape of independent publishing by seeking out both new and established poets whose work fell outside the mainstream. Today, BOA continues in this spirit by publishing new voices and providing a home for a diverse group of poets and writers. The books BOA publishes each year represent a diversity of voices, aesthetics, and forms. BOA and its authors have received many accolades and awards, including the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award. After nearly half a century of independent publishing, BOA remains steadfast in its mission to foster and promote readership of contemporary literature.

updates.update_content:
A note of gratitude from Aracelis Girmay
When Lucille Clifton was 10 years old she wrote the lines: “The world has writ the letter now, writ the letter now, ‘twas never wrote before.” These lines are the ones that breathe beneath my note to you now. The sound and wonder of them, but also the fact of the girl born Thelma Lucille Clifton, with twelve fingers, under a moon nearly half lit and half in shadow. Born through a poet into a poet, making a Dahomey sound in Buffalo, carrying anguish already, and making her poems before, after, through. Extraordinary and ordinary and Black and female and magic. It is very alphabet I walk behind listening toward the old, new sense she both awakens and makes possible with her work. I mean: courage is a word I know but sense differently as I follow the jagged route of that alphabet. Strangeness is a word I know but sense differently as I try to follow the route.

campaign.story:
For the past three years, we have played over 300 shows in 32 states and 157 different cities, and driven 72,000 miles. As we travel and explore the US by way of interstate highways, truck stops, and the couches of friends and friendly strangers, we have awakened to the beauty our own country and the myriad stories it has to tell.
Throughout this time we have been gathering and collecting images and stories and they have evolved into some of the most honest, fully-realized, and artistically cohesive songs that we've ever written.
And now we are ready to share these songs with the world...
How We Got Here
In 2014, you helped us create our debut album, What a Difference a Melody Makes. By helping us fund that album, you became an invaluable part of The Singer and The Songwriter. 
These past few years, as we have grown, and you have continued to support us: the generous friends-of-friends who have housed us; eager fans who have bought our albums, shared our music and hosted us for house concerts; and incredibly generous strangers who have welcomed us - you have all become our community and our family, and every tour, we look forward to seeing you and sharing our music and stories, triumphs and heartaches with you.
We've loved watching this community grow organically, and as we embark on our most ambitious collection of music yet, we are reaching out to you for support, inspiration, and encouragement. 
Modern Folk Songs
folk music (n.) music that originates in traditional popular culture or that is written in such a style. Folk music is typically [...] transmitted orally from generation to generation.
We’ve always had a connection to folk music because it is music about people. Throughout history, folk songs have served as documentation, a true account of our shared experiences. We have always been drawn to the humanity in these stories and how they bear witness to the truth. 
This is an album of modern folk songs, and these are true stories.
We have always had an “oral tradition” in the way we write since neither of us read or write music. We sing melodies back and forth to each other until something sticks. And through this imperfect oral tradition, the melody changes and morphs into a song. Thu will teach a song to Rachel and she will sing it back and eventually, Thu will sing Rachel’s version and Rachel will sing Thu’s version, and the final product is something wholly different than its origin. For us, that's folk music.
The Inspiration
The title for this album came from the town of McDermitt, NV - a small, “modern-day ghost town” on the border of Nevada and Oregon. There was an old abandoned shop with a sign in the window that read: Dreams! The Dead! Ghost! Future 
This intriguing series of words felt so evocative to us, and we felt that they perfectly captured the human experiences that we have been writing about in these new songs.
The Dreams... Team
Nick Luca - Producer/Engineer - We are enlisting a producer and engineer that we’ve admired for a long time: Nick Luca from Los Angeles, CA. He’s worked with Iron & Wine, Neko Case, and Calexico, and he mixed our second release, Ballads for Trying Times. His warmth, ease, and collaborative nature (as well as his multi-talented musicianship) make him the perfect person to bring these songs to life.
JJ Golden - Mastering Engineer - For our past two releases, we have loved working with JJ Golden and the team at Golden Mastering in Ventura, CA. JJ has lent his light touch, and incredible breadth of experience to our music and has contributed so much to our recordings. We are excited for him to master this album.
We will also be bringing on a drummer and bass player for this album as well as a few other musicians as needed, and we are excited to introduce them to you as they sign on for the project! 
The Timeline
In early 2020, we will join Nick in Los Angeles to track and mix 10-12 songs for this album over the course of about 2 weeks. From there, we will send the final mixes to Golden Mastering with a goal to have a completed album that's ready for release in late spring of 2020.
The Budget
We want to be transparent with you about exactly where all the funds will go for this project.
 36% of the funds will go to paying our producer and the studio rental 
 15% of the funds will go to the post-production process (i.e. mixing and mastering)
 15% of the funds will go to a promotional campaign for the album's release
 17% of the funds will go to manufacturing merchandise (CD's, Vinyl, T-shirts, and more!)
 8% of funds will go to the various fees from Kickstarter and Amazon
The remaining 9% of funds and anything over our goal will go toward making music videos, creating more great merch for you, and extra promotional efforts for the album's release.
Folk of Color
We consider our diverse cultural backgrounds (Vietnamese-American and mixed-race Mexican-American) to be unique assets in creating folk music. We are proud to carry on the folk music tradition of sharing our perspective and experience of the world through music and storytelling, and we feel that the representation of our identities as people of color in this field is important. We have always had a goal of inclusivity in our music, and we hope that through our inclusion in the folk music community, we inspire the inclusion of others as well.

Most of the songs on this album are finished and ready to record, but a few are still in the process of being written, so there is a chance that there may be a delay in completing the arrangements in order to be ready for the studio. This may push the recording process back a few weeks. 

There is also a chance that post-production and mixing may take a few passes, since we want these songs to sound their best before we release them. In which case, this may delay the manufacturing of CD's and Vinyl.

We are a two-person operation - from graphic design to marketing to booking - we do it all. We have created these timelines for ourselves to be accountable, but being independent means that we are also able to adjust our timeline in order to honor the integrity of the music and the quality that it calls for. Our dearest friends and backers,
It’s been a long time since we last updated you and we thought it was time for us to check in with you to let you know about the status of our album.
First off, we want to thank you for being patient with us as we navigate this year of change. We are still very much committed to the creation of this album, though the timeline has been pushed back. As of now, our plan is to try and record the album with our producer later this year or early 2021, whenever it will be safe for us to travel to LA to record. Once we have a definitive timeframe for our recording dates, you'll be the first to know our updated release date. Rest assured, we are still planning on delivering all the planned rewards.

campaign.story:
Object of Her Affection is a solo object and puppet-based performance art piece centered on a woman, who in her search for true love develops intimate relationships with inanimate objects. 
Created by Marsian De Lellis, and directed by Michele Spears, this unconventional love story explores the synesthetic relationship between objects and personalities, and ways that objects can occupy more than one meaning at any given time.  There will be twelve performances over three weekends from September 27th and October 13th at Automata in Los Angeles as part of Los Angeles Exchange [LAX] Festival, 6th Ed.
2014, Automata, Photo: Rafael Hernandez
The Story
Object of Her Affection follows the emotional journey of protagonist, Andrea Lowe, after she has mysteriously fallen from a building.  In her final moments, she reflects on her meaningful relationships starting with her first love, a baby’s blanket.  As an adolescent, she loses her virginity to a bad-boy hunting rifle and subsequently becomes infatuated with a controversial wall.  As Andrea evolves, so do her desires. In adulthood, she forms doomed relationships with monumental structures: a high-profile statue, tragic twin skyscrapers, and a bridge who cheats.  Each of these relationships has a profound effect, shaping Andrea’s views on life and love. Finally,  she finds solace in Roy, a crumbling tenement who ultimately fails her. 
The Performance
Object of Her Affection is a visual narrative about human beings (flesh and blood) developing intimate relationships with inanimate things and the universal development and loss of relationships we encounter on our journey through life.
 “The piece, which questions on a cosmic level our artificial divide between the animate and the inanimate, has the appealing, droll humor and structural unity of a David Sedaris story.” – LA Weekly
2014, REDCAT, Photo: Steve Gunther
Inspiration
I’ve been developing the ideas behind Object of Her Affection for a while: Back in 2010 -  my wheels started spinning when I stumbled upon footage of a woman who wanted to marry an amusement park ride.  While her story was unusual, there was something about her authenticity and earnestness that was relatable and refreshing.
As an artist who recontextualizes objects and puppets, I’m constantly thinking about animism and the suspension of disbelief.  As a queer person, object sexuality resonated with something inside me that had been festering: on the one hand sexual minorities were making historic strides. On the other it seemed like LGBT identity was being gentrified in a heteronormative push towards respectability politics.  
You bet I was fascinated by the concept of object sexuality.  There was something appealing about the emotional, physical, and romantic desire towards inanimate objects.  It explodes traditional categorizations of sexual identity and turns our ideas about love inside out.  People with object sexuality fall in love with things, rather than humans.  They don’t so much want a place at the table as they might long for a relationship with one.
2016, Los Angeles Municipal Art Gallery, photos: Alex Griffin
History
There have been many iterations of the material from this project in the last eight years from artist talks (Calgary’s International Festival of Animated Objects, Maryland Institute College of Art), readings and workshops (Eugene O‘Neill Theater Center, Automata, REDCAT), to an installation at Los Angeles Municipal Art Gallery in which I created over a thousand distressed handmade rag dolls. 
It’s 2018, and I’m thrilled Los Angeles Performance Practice has invited us to perform at Automata for a three-weekend run. It has been a dream of mine to have a longer run where more people can experience Object of Her Affection. I hope through wider exposure, the performance will one day be able tour. Your support will help me to create a dynamic performance that occupies a precarious border between beauty and terror as I further examine the fringes of our shared world.  
We need your help!
With your help I hope to raise a minimum of $3,000 to addresses urgent, necessary artist fees and production costs crucial to the project’s completion. Your donations will ensure we can present the performance in the best possible light by completing our lighting, projection, and sound budget items. Anything raised towards our stretch goal of $10,000 will help increase production value, take some financial strain off mounting a large scale production, and put us in a better position for future runs and touring possibilities  
2016, Haus of Marsian, Photo: William Short
Creative Team
Marsian De Lellis (writer, performer, creator) is an interdisciplinary artist who combines sculpture, objects, installation, performance and handmade spectacles to memorialize obsessional lives. Their work celebrates stories of unconventional people whose private manias become public fodder for tabloids and reality television. 
Michele Spears (director) is a director/choreographer, performer, theatre producer, and arts educator. Her work has been recognized with New York Nightlife, L.A. Weekly, Saturn, UNIMA, Stagescene L.A., Dramalogue, and Santa Barbara Independent Awards, as well as American Choreographers Award  and Ovation Award nominations.
Andrew Schmedake (Lighting designer) is a lighting designer for theater, dance and live events. His career has ranged from opera and ballet to cruise ships, haunted houses and immersive theater. Presently, Andrew lives in Los Angeles and lectures at UC Santa Barbara. He earned his MFA in Lighting Design from Carnegie Mellon University.
Becca Kessin (sound designer) is a sound designer working in Los Angeles and regionally since 2006. She teaches Sound Design at California State University, Fullerton, after previously teaching at Santa Monica College, Cal Poly Pomona, and the Orange County High School for the Arts. Seeing her students flourish in their chosen field brings her great joy.

Rewards
As a thank you for your support, we’re offering a number of exciting awards!  At the “FWB” ($10) level, we’ll acknowledge your alluring micro-philanthropy online + social media, so friends, family, co-workers, and foreign adversaries will all know how generous you are. Or for slightly more, at the “Discreet” ($25) level, we’ll try to be  “discreet” (whatever that means) about your generosity and NOT acknowledge your allure on social media. Note: We can’t exactly guarantee foreign adversaries won’t find out how kind you are, and reserve the right to print your name in the program + websites)
Is anything ever safe? At the “Safe Word” ($50) level, we’ll send a digital pdf of the script you can read anywhere. “Safe Word” is ideal for waiting rooms or plane rides (where nosey seat mates can look over your shoulder and speculate about you). There’s also the printed “Sapio” ($69) option signed by the writer and sealed in an envelope licked with the writer’s own saliva. This hard copy is a much sought after night stand (or jury duty) conversation starter. 
We know many of you want the performance to tour to your far away city, or maybe you live in L.A., but don't want to get out of bed. No worries!  We’ve got you covered with the “Voyeur” ($113) reward. You’ll receive private downloadable videos from our newly edited 51-minute Automata workshop and 29-minute REDCAT performance (both 2014) and any new bonus footage as it becomes available.
Show your soft, yet aggressive side at the “Rough Trade” ($160/$169+) level, with a miniature (4”-6”), cardboard taxidermized feline head. These cruelty-free, artesanal handmade items, are the purrr-fect holiday gift that can diffuse the fiercest of vegangelical friends (or that family member with Social Justice Disorder). Every reward at the “Rough Trade” level and beyond comes with or without the plus option with tickets for Angelenos and LA visitors. Plus tickets are made available on a first-come, first-reserve basis. 
At the “Situationship” ($260/$269+) level, you can adopt your very own small* (4”-6”) distressed, handmade rag doll from the “(In)/Animate Objects” collection. Situationship dolls could be a thoughtful winter solstice gift for that FWB who may be agnostic, buddhist, or in some form of bereavement. Contemplate impermanence as you watch this one of a kind art piece decay over time.  The “Situationship” reward is also available with 2 tickets (for you and an emotional service human).
At the “Gainer” ($560/569+) level, you can own a large 12” tall* distressed, handmade, artist rag doll from the “(In)/Animate Objects” collection. Ruminate into the tangles of dysfunctional primitive stitchery, brooding over the ephemeral nature of life and the inevitability of death, while your doll slowly deteriorates right before your eyes. Indulge yourself in mock burials, or invest in your contemporary art collection. “Gainer” level dolls come with the option of 2 tickets. Suggested: bring an ex to the performance and bestow upon them this charming closure gift before you abandon each other. 
Both “Situationship” and “Gainer” level dolls are sourced from the "(In)/Animate Objects" collection, a 2016 installation that formed the second half of a diptych with its companion, the performance, "Object of Her Affection". In the installation, years have passed since Andrea fatally fell from the crumbling tenement she was in love with.  In a dark room, a mountain of decaying dolls tower to the ceiling upon which their maker, Andrea’s grandmother, presides from the throne of her wingback chair. The thousands of dolls she has amassed in sorrow testify to the insatiable need for love at the heart of the obsessional life. *Note: “Situationship” and “Gainer” level dolls are designed to be irregular, and may come burned, stained, soiled, and/or damaged with evidence of wear and tear. 
I am also designing a small but sensual, limited edition, signed photo book of images and ephemera from our performances at the “Pornographer” ($360/$369+) level.  A delightfully provocative conversation piece, the “Pornographer” level art book, comes with the option of 2 tickets for you and a trick.
Finally, at the “Throuple” ($960/969) level you’ll triple your pleasure with three rewards: a unique 12” “Gainer” level artist doll, a visually stimulating “Pornographer” level photo book, and a “Rough Trade” level Cardboard Taxidermy collectable... But why be a basic throuple when you could be a power throuple?  With the plus 3-ticket option , you could spice up poly date night with your primary and metamour.

Wow, where to begin... well, my name is Marcelino Feliciano and I'd like to thank you for taking the time to visit this page and read about me and my project.
As I embark on my first official CD recording and it's subsequent release, I am filled with excitement, joy, fear and trepidation all wrapped up in one! Excitement and joy because it's an honor to be given the gift of music and have the opportunity to share it with the world. I've been blessed to have the good fortune to do what I love, sing, and sing jazz to be more specific. I've shared the stage with many great jazz musicians and have been mentored by them. I've traveled abroad to perform this music and every time I do there is the same excitement and joy I felt when I was a kid.
Still, I would be lying if I didn't say I felt a bit of fear and trepidation as I move forward in this next chapter of my musical career. Putting forth my original compositions and the arrangements that have been swirling around in my head is a bit daunting. But fear of the unknown is a wonderful place for a jazz musician to be in and I accept the challenge wholeheartedly.
 I was asked by my friend, pianist/composer/producer Bill Mays, "Why now? What took so long?", and the truth is, I wasn't ready. Jazz is a process. It's about growth and maturity. It's about the experience one gains from playing and living this great music and hopefully developing a sound or voice that's uniquely your own.
On my debut CD, I hope to share with you original compositions and standards that are personal to me. I have been busy writing and arranging songs that express where I am today both musically and emotionally. Songs and ideas that convey the things that excite me and concern me, the choices that shaped my life and the emotions I feel when I think about the beauty and immensity of this world. For those of you who have seen me perform you know what I mean. I leave it all out for you to enjoy!
Joining me on this project will be, my collaborator, Nicki Adams. Nicki is an emotionally sensitive pianist, amazing technician and my partner in fleshing out musical ideas and arrangements. He is also a fine composer in his own right. It's important for a singer to have a pianist you can work with consistently and he has been an integral part of this journey. He along with a rhythm section will comprise the nucleus of the band for this project.
In closing, know that I regard your contribution, no matter how large or small, as a gracious gesture and I recognize that I'm blessed that you believe in me. The decision is personal. Remember, all of your contributions will help pay for my wonderful musicians, the studio time and sound engineer, mixing & mastering and, of course, the photography, artwork and manufacturing that will send this record out into the world. Choose from the list of pledges on the right of this page at whatever fits your budget or moves your soul. The rewards are great, but the greatest reward for you, is knowing that you’ve contributed to the arts and an artist who's project you believe in. I invite you to come on this journey with me!
Remember time is short and we only have 31 days to raise $15,000 or more. If we don't reach our goal, the project is cancelled and your money refunded. But not to worry, I believe we can make this happen. Your contributions will help make this project come true!
Marcelino Feliciano

SHORT STORY: 
2 new songs. 2 videos. Empathy, evolution and beauty. We humbly ask for your support to fulfill these musical promises.
THANK YOU! 
-----
LOOONG STORY
THE PERSONAL: 
It’s been 8 years – almost to the day – since I decided I was going to be a rock star. In that time I’ve put out two demos, two EPs, a live album, a full length album, a Folk Opera (with my first Kickstarter campaign in 2010), six professional videos and a series of commissioned works for the Puppets & Poets Festival 2015. I've landed two licensing contracts (which have yet to place anything), started on the road towards the professional songwriting/publishing world, quit my day job twice and restarted it once. 
And, between growing and birthing a child and a hard turn a few years back, my sense of the world has exploded open and everything that’s come before has been rewritten with the new knowledge of the suffering and miracles of existence. 
During some of that less desirable time – when the first truth of Buddhism (“All life is suffering”) suddenly became apparent – I experienced my first creative block. I was paralyzed in the lower regions of Maslow’s hierarchy while we weathered some vast unknowns regarding the child’s health*. It was a sort of torture. But like all things in time, it changed, and here I am today exploding with creative energy, writing better music than ever, and almost singularly focused on bringing it into the world in its proper format. 
For me, these songs represent not only the more universal themes described below, but also a personal evolution: since those hard times I have been constantly living in them, cycling through bouts of despair and gratitude. These songs have helped me learn to tuck despair into my heart, a constant companion, and keep moving along anyway. We are all suffering in our own ways, but we are not suffering all the time, as a great friend helped me remember. These songs are meant to both bridge an understanding to the suffering of their subjects, but also bring light and beauty to life. 
(*HE IS GLORIOUSLY HEALTHY NOW! All is well. Blessed be.)  
THE MUSIC: 
My mission is to build empathic bridges between people. The new songs do this exponentially better than anything I’ve written before. Empathy has always been my impetus, but now I truly break and am reborn in the stories of people I meet, love, or have known. 
Why does empathy matter? Empathy hurts. It requires courage and vulnerability over and over. It is not easy. But, with empathy we put aside our personal fears and assumptions and listen to what someone else is saying. And we feel what they feel for a moment – our bridge to them. We’re then less likely to hate them, judge them, or ignore systems that hurt them. I believe this is our best tool in the fight against the hate that surrounds us in the present age.
 “What We Said” – This song, with newly edited lyrics, is written in the voice of a woman who refuses to leave her husband (until death) even though he cheats. We want to judge this woman – and so many are– for this decision, but we don’t understand her. The conflict here is between personal happiness and the devotion to a vow. (Hear the old lyric-version here, to get the haunting melody and Jeremy's sick bass line stuck in your head.)  

“Nikki’s Song” – (A working title) An ode to the stupendous Nicole McRory (whose body left us 5 years ago April 29th), a transsexual woman and rock goddess like none other. This song gives voice not only to a tiny fraction of her struggle as a trans person, but also her courage as someone who never gave up keeping her heart open to the pain and beauty of the world ... with a strong nod to the Beckett’s Family Reunion that happened every Wednesday night from 2002-2007. The song is for and from Nikki - the last line ("Just like she feared / Her life fell apart / But that's the way / She'd always say / You earn your Diamond Heart") came to me while Emmylou Harris sang "The Pearl" ten feet in front of me in Nashville a few weeks ago - it felt like a gift from Nicole. Not a bad way to receive a song-gift ... (It was effing amazing actually.)
Annie & Nikki
Both songs lean back towards the electric sounds of light to see dark, our 2012 album, leaving behind most of the acoustic instrumentation of Stranded Songs (except Jeremy’s u-bass ☺). As always, we keep strong the folk roots and pop sensibilities. Tal Ariel will be lending his expertise as a Producer to these tunes, and we’ll have a few special guests sitting in with us. 
We'll also be creating a video for each song. This is one of the best and most compelling ways that people discover and share music these days and we consider it essential to the process. We'll have more details on this as we confirm our collaborators. 
We see a big life for these songs. Bigger than any song I've released before. 
THE TEAM
The efforts of Jeremy Mulder (my sweet love) and dear friends Tal Ariel and Omar Cuellar during the last few years have been loving and full of excitement. These men don’t just show up and play, they work on arrangements, help with production decisions, make me laugh, and encourage me to keep working. Not to mention their immense talent uplifting my work at every turn. 
five people, four males, three beards, two mulders & one Bacon
We also have on board collaborators old and new: Gabriel Goldstein, who directed, shot and/or edited this, this, and this video of ours; Do I Dare, who remixed this song and this one of ours; Bunnie Reiss, who made the dress below and is my FAVORITE contemporary artist (she's creating an original piece of art for us); 25th Street Recording studios; and more!
The Team is ready!

Full funding of the project is $7,000. If we raise $10,000 our videos will be properly funded, at $14,000 we can do an additional day of recording (1-2 more songs), and if you INSIST that we do a whole album, help us get to $20,000. 
For years now I've been skimping and making magic happen by asking people to volunteer their efforts - including many of you. And what magic!!! But that is unsustainable. If there’s a shorthand version of the transformation of Brooklyn in recent years, it goes something like this: Gritty, rundown district gets rediscovered by young people with a vision, who start bands and open coffee bars and mayonnaise stores, leading to an urban renaissance. Or, if you’re of a different ideological bent — or someone who’s gotten evicted to make way for a mayonnaise store — replace “young people” with “developers and gentrifiers” and “start bands” with “destroy everything that was once good about the place.”
It’s the same story as in numerous other cities, where “revitalized” urban neighborhoods have sprung up in recent years, germinating Thai takeout and juice bars wherever they go.
Yet the real story of the New Brooklyn is far more complex. It's a tale of quick-buck land flippers and city officials playing cat-and-mouse as each pursue their own self-interested ends; of artists and entrepreneurs and sideshow hucksters seeking to claim neighborhoods for their own, while at the same time hoping to fight off the next wave of colonists who invariably follow them; of unemployed master puppeteers on soup kitchen lines and longtime shopkeepers alike trying to fight through the tidal surge of the new Brooklyn economy; and of young newcomers who seek apartments by riding the L train until they find a neighborhood they can afford. All are helping to shape Brooklyn in their own way, though some are more influential shapers than others.
These are just some of the people you’ll meet in “The Brooklyn Wars,” a full-length book that will zoom in on four key battlegrounds in the borough’s transformation:
• The redevelopment of Coney Island, which began as a complicated four-way battle between amusement park operators, city planners, real estate magnates, and low-income residents. It's resulted in a beachfront that has been transformed, but not in ways that everyone agrees is for the better.
• Downtown Brooklyn and Bushwick, two neighborhoods on the front lines of the borough’s gentrification battles, pitting longtime residents against wealthier (and whiter) newcomers.
• The outer Brooklyn neighborhoods, from eastern Bedford-Stuyvesant to Flatlands and Canarsie, where most of the borough’s one million poor live, and where economic benefits haven’t always trickled down.
• The new Barclays Center arena for the Brooklyn Nets, which sparked a decade-long fight over “jobs, hoops, and housing” involving the strangest of bedfellows.
These are all areas that I’ve covered extensively for more than a decade, for such publications as the Village Voice, City Limits, and Metro NY. (See demause.net for links to recent articles.) “The Brooklyn Wars” will take the best of this reporting — including a backlog of material that wouldn’t fit into a 500-word op-ed column — and mix it with new research to create an all-new work intended to answer the question: How has Brooklyn changed, who are the winners and losers, and what does this mean for other cities facing similar transformations?
So why, exactly, do I need your help with this? Right now, I have tons of stories to tell, but they’re scattered across dozens of articles in multiple outlets (many no longer available online), not to mention countless notebooks and minidisc cartridges that have piled up over the years. Your donation will not only help me research my research, as it were, but to conduct new investigations as well. Add in time for layout (I have book production in my bag of tricks as well) and some professional illustrators (very much not in my bag), and your funding is what will make it all possible.
Plus, of course, you’ll get all the nifty rewards shown at right — including, if you so choose, an actual physical book, printed via Createspace and mailed to you via the U.S. Postal Service. Just like people used to buy in the old Brooklyn.
Huge thanks to David Dyte, author of As Seen In Brooklyn, for the use of two of his photos in the above video, and to Tara Key and the wonderful band Antietam for use of their song “The Gate Closed” off their 2008 album Opus Mixtum. Once you’re done supporting my project, please go support theirs as well at the included links.

"Rather like the great experiment that was avant-garde theater in New York for the second half of the 20th century. Behind the Lid is an evocation not only of Ms. Nagrin but also of an entire theatrical subculture that now has only a flickering existence."
                            - Ben Brantley, The New York Times.  2007
THE STORY
Lee Nagrin was a pivotal and influential figure in the Avant-Garde movement of the second half of the 20th century.  She had a immeasurable impact on countless downtown artists thriving today.  With her assimilation of many artistic mediums, Nagrin was considered a multi-media artist long before the term was even invented.   
Behind The Lid,  a theatrical experience created slowly over nine years by Lee Nagrin and world-renowned puppeteer Basil Twist, received its world premiere on June 3, 2007 at the Silver Whale Gallery in New York City to great critical acclaim. It ran for only 6 weeks. 
The intimate audience of 18 people per-performance took an expanded and revealing journey through a special hand-made world. Twist and four puppeteers performed alongside effigies and totems of Nagrin. Her longtime home and work space, Silver Whale Gallery at 21 Bleecker Street, was utterly transformed into in a site-specific and ambulatory experience, delving into Nagrin’s personal history and that of the 20th century.
Lee died on June 7, 2007, just 4 days after the premiere, and her Silver Whale Gallery no longer exists.  
The film of Behind the Lid is one of the remaining preservations of her work.  It was shot directly after the close of the run, performed solely for the cameras over 2 days, before the sets, puppets and props were permanently struck.  The phantom camera takes you through the performance experience as if you were the sole person seeing it, and also from the perspective of the puppet effigy of Lee.  The film is both an elegy and a unique document of this sensory theatrical event.
Reviews of the original BEHIND THE LID production:
Ben Brantley. NY Times. 6.16.2007
Helen Shaw. New York Sun. 6.19.2007
"Hiroshima" scene. Photo Credit: Richard Termine
From the film's director: 
Back in July 2007, when my friend Basil Twist approached me to film his and Lee Nagrin's theater piece Behind the Lid, I came to it as most of the audience did - ready for wonder, embracing mystery, and open to the adventure. Due to its limited run and access, I saw the show just once in preparation, but it was indelibly seared in my brain. I never met Lee in this world, but certainly met her in the world she created here with Basil. To describe it more would tell you what to expect or how to feel, and I'd rather you discover that through this film.
Benevolent and talented colleagues from Basil and Lee's team joined together with my team to preserve art, and make art.  We captured Behind the Lid in marathon sessions, rough and tumble in just 2 days, but with a vision to translate and preserve Basil and Lee's bold and astonishing work to another medium.  Thanks to the generosity of Kodak, we shot on 16mm, in homage to Lee's earlier films.  To me, the textures and colors feel like memory.
This is a feature-length film documentary of a narrative performance experience unlike anything else, shot under remarkably limited conditions, driven by creative instinct, adrenaline, and above all, purpose.  Yet, from chaos comes beauty.
Now, with your care and support, we'll see it finished in 2014. That we may succeed, with your generosity, is cause for reflection and celebration.  Lee is gone.  The sets are gone.  The landscape that nurtures this kind of theater has dwindled.  The end of shooting on film is declared near.  And yet, here we are, with all the spirits and mediums preserved.
With this film of Behind the Lid - and your help to finish it - we'll have created a portal and a conduit to the seemingly ephemeral. Trust me, this is to be treasured.
- Steve Lippman aka Flip.  NYC, 2014
GOALS and WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT
The filming of Behind the Lid took place on July 8th and 9th, 2007.  The shoot was made possible by the generous donations of talent and services behind and in front of the camera.  Any essential financial commitments were covered by private donors, before the advent of outlets like Kickstarter.  
During the shoot, we were usually limited to just 2 or 3 takes of each scene, covered by two 16mm cameras, given our limited supply of film stock.  
The exposed 16mm was transferred and archived to HD.  Through additional private donor funding,  the film was then edited on and off over a period of 6 weeks in 2008, covering about 40 minutes of the final estimated 90 minutes.  The film and project has laid dormant since then. 
The desire to finish the film has always been there, but resources, schedules and the progress of other creative endeavors would push it to "next year."  And of course, there was the question of funding such a specialized work. 
Now, with the outlet of Kickstarter and your help, we can realistically finish the film to the point where it can finally be screened at film festivals, museums, and arts events. 
The money raised will cover the following:
• Editorial
• Color correction
• Titles/credit design
• Additional dialogue recording/dubbing
• Sound mix
• Screening / archive masters
As many of you may know, but worth repeating,  we only are funded if we make our Kickstarter goal.  This is an all or nothing proposition.  We have set our total at the lowest possible to complete our goals.  Finishing with this budget will still require heavily reduced fees, and lots of in-kind favors, but we know we can do it.   
If we are lucky enough, thanks to you, to reach and exceed our goal, then rest assured that there's still use for your funding. There's a whole other level to achieve that will enable us to bring the film to an even wider audience than our initial sights.  But first, let's climb this initial plateau.
Thank you for joining us on this journey.
 ABOUT THE ARTISTS
Original Behind the Lid Production Credits: 
Co-Created by Lee Nagrin and Basil Twist • Directed & Design by Basil Twist • Costume Design by Sally Ann Parsons • Lighting Design by Tony Giovanetti • Projection Design by Daniel Brodie • Sound Design by Moira MacDonald • Performed by Basil Twist, Oliver Dalzell, Yvette Edery, Randy Ginsburg, Kirsten Kammermeyer and Jamie Moore.
Principal film production:  Jeremy Kotin, Shane Sigler, David Teague and David Bartolomi.  Thanks to Anne Hubbell at Kodak.
LEE NAGRIN was a visual artist, performer, singer, choreographer, director and playwright. She is considered one of America’s first women performance artists and a pioneer in the field of interdisciplinary performance work.  Her highly original and unflinching vision has led to the creation of richly layered work that has been described as "pure image-theatre magic."
Nagrin moved to New York in 1950 and became a major force in the Off-Broadway theatre scene for more than forty years. She was instrumental in the development of several Off-Broadway theatres, including the Sullivan Street Playhouse, the Bridge Theatre, Theatre One and the Downtown Theatre. She produced, directed / or performed in some ten Off-Broadway productions between 1950 and 1963, and was first to produce the work of Ionesco in the U.S.
In 1958, Nagrin appeared alongside Steve McQeen in the cult film The Blob, and was offered a four-year studio contract by Paramount. Nagrin declined the offer in order to pursue a creative life in New York City.
From 1971 to 1981, Nagrin was a member of Meredith Monk’s company The House, with whom she developed and performed in a number of works: Paris/Chacon/Venice/Milan (1970) Vessel (1971) Education of a Girl Child (1974) (Ping Chong and Monk) Small Scroll (1975) Quarry (1976) Recent Ruins (1979) and Ellis Island (1981).
In 1975, Nagrin directed Eric Slazman’s Lazarus. In 1975-76 Nagrin co-created Stings with Margaret Beals which premiered at London’s ICA in 1977 and was performed in New York at Kaufmann Hall of the 92nd Street Y and at the Playwright’s Horizon.
Nagrin formed her own company the Sky Fish Ensemble in 1979 and created and directed the following: Sky Fish (1979) and Bird/Devil (1980) which were performed at the Silver Whale Gallery, New York. In June/July of 1982, Whorl was performed at Danspace, St. Mark’s Church, New York. All these works were produced by the Women’s Interart Center. In 1986, Nagrin premiered two works: Bone Orchard and Bird/Bear. The latter won an OBIE Award for Best New American Play. In 1990, Dragon’s Nest was presented at La Mama Annex in association with Women’s Interart Center.  Angels Elegy (1994) premiered at the Silver Whale Gallery. In 1995, a video production of Sky Fish was added to the Museum of Modern Art Film Archive Collection. In 1997, Nagrin directed Pathways by choreographer Margaret Beals, which The Boston Globe included as its "Best Theatre Works" of the year. In 2000, The Valley of Iao was presented at La Mama Annex, co-produced by La Mama in association with Dance Street Productions.
Nagrin also performed in the following Karen Malpede’s plays: Blue Heaven (1992) at Theatre for the New City, and a workshop production of Beekeeper’s Daughter (1994-95) in a role wrote for her that toured Italy. In 1995 she performed in Foundry Theatre’s production of Deviant Craft by OBIE Award winning playwright W. David Hancock , at Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage.  Nagrin’s last play was "Behind the Lid."
www.leenagrin.com
BASIL TWIST is originally from San Francisco.  Twist is a third generation puppeteer whose original productions include Symphonie Fantastique, La Bella Dormente Nel Bosco, Hansel and Gretel, Behind The Lid, Arias with a Twist, Seafoam Sleepwalk and The Rite of Spring. 
Broadway credits include The Pee Wee Herman Show and The Addams Family. In San Francisco his credits include his original Dogugaeshi at Cal Performances, Wonderboy with Joe Goode Performance Group, and The Long Christmas Ride Home at Magic Theater. 
He has received an Obie and Drama Desk Award, five UNIMA Awards, two Bessie Awards, a Henry Hewes Award, a Guggenheim and USA Artists fellowships, and a Doris Duke Performing Artist Award.  
In 2012 the city of Washington D.C. hosted a retrospective of his work. He will collaborate with Wheeldon on The Winter's Tale for the Royal Ballet in London this April.  He lives in NYC, where he guides The Dream Music Puppetry Program at HERE.   www.basiltwist.com
STEVE LIPPMAN aka FLIP's credits include acclaimed music short films, documentaries and music videos conceived and directed for David Bowie, Laurie Anderson, Dolly Parton, Esperanza Spalding, Carly Simon, Bette Midler, Trixie Whitley, Jorge Drexler, Joe Henry, Kronos Quartet, Rumer, k.d. lang, Madeleine Peyroux, Youssou N'Dour, Bonnie Raitt, Sam Phillips and many more.
Flip's work has been screened at film festivals worldwide including Cannes, London, Berlin, Sao Poalo, Nashville, Tribeca, Denver and more. Dedicated programs of his work have been held at the Music Doc Fest/Malmo, Sweden, Sound Unseen Film Festival, Minneapolis, MN, and In-Edit/Barcelona film festivals.   Imagery from his music films was featured in major concert tours for David Bowie, Rosanne Cash, and Dolly Parton. 
The director's documentary feature film Stay All Night is in pre-production, anticipating a 2015 release.  Stay All Night is a kaleidoscopic dazzling show-business and social meditation on the profound bond between Judy Garland and her audience, the nature of memory, and New York City in an era of pivotal change, seen through the prism of Garland's legendary Carnegie Hall concert of April 23rd, 1961, as told by those who were there. The film is executive produced by Academy Award winners Rob Epstein & Jeffrey Friedman.
Flip resides in Brooklyn, New York, but works globally.

campaign.story:
Stretch Goal
This project made its funding on December 4. It all happened suddenly toward the end, so there was not time to write about stretch goals. A "stretch goal" is a new or added goal, beyond the original goal, in the event the project exceeds its funding. In our case, we have a number of people lined up who are ready to pledge, so I want to emphasize that we can still take those additional pledges and that they will continue to advance our cause. Here, then, is our stretch goal.
Funds beyond our target will go toward a commission. We will approach Johnny Simons with a proposal that he create a new original theatre work that will complement the archived works on our website. The idea is that he will write a piece -- perhaps to be premiered at the Hip Pocket Theatre in 2014 -- that will round out the works that we are digitizing from the early Simons and Balentine years. We will find a way to videotape the performance, using some of the digitizing/editing activities that will be underway at that time. This -- the newest in a long line of Simons originals -- will then cap the website archives, demonstrating the ongoing vitality and creativity of live original theatre in Fort Worth.
We hope that we can raise enough in these final countdown hours to award this special commission to Johnny as a special thank you for his prolific output, and as a tribute to Douglas and their very special creative relationship. So please, keep those pledges coming!
New pledges from this point may request that donor names be associated with this new commission, as well as with the website itself.
Project in a Nutshell
At the end of this one-year project there will exist a website with 25-30 of Doug and Johnny's shows (video and audio), plus early home-made tapes, garage recordings, and the visual reference material that goes with them. An archive if you will, of the important collaboration between Johnny Simons and Douglas Balentine in those early years of the seventies and eighties at Fort Worth's Hip Pocket Theatre.
Background
My name is Bruce Balentine, but this project is not about me; it is about my brother, Douglas. I want to preserve his music and see it live again. Doug worked for some 30 years with Johnny Simons—his collaborator, mentor, friend, and soul-brother—producing innova­tive musical theatre in Fort Worth, Texas. Johnny wrote the scripts and lyrics, Doug composed the music. Johnny directed and cho­reographed; Doug played piano, assembled the musicians and rehearsed the singers. In 1977, they and Johnny’s wife Diane founded Hip Pocket Theatre, a Fort Worth institution. You can learn more about them here:
http://www.hippocket.org
The theater is still flourishing today, and will be starting its 38th season in June 2014.
The image above shows Doug at his keyboard at the original Hip Pocket Theatre on Highway 80 (1979). The theatre moved later to two subsequent sites, but always retained the rustic and improvised texture that is its unique trademark -- as if the theatre and its music grew spontaneously right up from the scrub brush and oak trees on the west side of Fort Worth.
Douglas died in 2008. He left behind a room full of reel-to-reel and cassette tapes: more than 30 full-length musical theatre pieces, plus albums, songs, half-finished scraps, and the scores, scripts, and printed materials that go with them. Some of the most beautiful music I’ve ever heard lies buried in those tapes; and some of the most moving lyrics, Johnny’s lyrics, are brought alive by Doug’s musical in­terpretation and by the stories and staging captured on the ¾-inch U-Matic video cassettes filling a second storage room.
 The Problem
These old analog tapes are degrading with each passing day that we do not digitize them. I have devoted much of the past four years to converting those tapes into digital form. I al­ready have more than 50 hours of material on my hard drives. Digitized music is in the form of 44.1 KHz stereo .wav files, and video is MPEG2. But it is very time-consuming, and I have a full-time job. I am increasingly worried that the material is vanishing faster than I can get to it.
The Solution
What’s needed is a professional who is paid to do the digitizing. This professional needs to have the following skills:
Knowledge of analog tape formats;
Skill with tape splicing;
Skill with tape “cooking”;
Ability to handle NAB hubs and reels; and,
Ability to edit multimedia (audio & video) files on computer.
We have located and lined up those professionals. But it costs money. The first phase of this project involves getting these fragile tapes digitized and secure.
Doug and Johnny don their tuxedos for picture call in the dance studio (1980)
Doug and Johnny shortly before Doug’s death (2008)
Phase I: There are three phases to our plan. The first is by far the most important: digitizing the analog tapes to stop their continued degradation. We have found several firms able to do this work both in San Antonio (where most of the tapes are) and in Fort Worth (where video cassettes are stored). My brother Jim is in San Antonio to supervise the tape work there, and—since the Hip Pocket Theatre is located in Fort Worth—that area holds many long-time aficionados who can help with labeling and indexing. During digitizing, the transfer specialists will set levels and ensure the best copy. They will also encounter old worn-out splices and broken tapes, requiring splicing and other repairs. In some cases they must “cook” the tapes (due to an unfortunate design flaw in a particular brand of Ampex recording tape popular at the time). We have the appropriate tape decks, cooking and splicing equipment and will provide them to the audio company. We will also work closely with them to assist in this digitizing phase.
Here is a breakdown of the tape collection:
115 reel-to-reel tapes (7" and 10.5")
165 audio cassettes
90 video cassettes (VHS)
75 video cassettes (3/4" U-Matic)
That's 280 audio and 165 video tapes -- a total of 445 tapes representing some 720 hours of material. Many of the tapes will run easily at real-time (for example, it's been my experience doing this in my home studio that most of the cassettes have remained in good shape and experience no problems). Others -- the larger R2R tapes especially -- will exhibit a lot of damage. We'll go from easy to hard to make the early phase produce output quickly. Almost half of the budget is targeted at Phase I based on the expectation that we'll experience problems with about a third of the R2R tapes but little problem with the rest.
Phase I digitizing will require six months.
Phase II: Once we have the tapes in digital form, we can distribute the rest of the archiving effort thoughtfully across many people The second phase is for organizing, labeling, tagging, and preparing the material for uploading. Most of this work will be done by me at no cost, but some significant budget is set aside for data entry and cataloguing tasks that must be done by team members associated with the Hip Pocket Theatre. Peggy Bott Kirby is the main person assigned this task. We expect to receive offers of assistance by the many scores of Hip Pocket exes who have enjoyed this remarkable theatre for so many years to help with this effort instead of (or in addition) to their backing pledges, as described in the rewards. Phase II will require six months.
Phase III: The third phase develops the website and populates it with these materials -- audio, video, and images. Much of the work can be done by website talent already working with the theatre -- for example Robert Bourdage -- who maintains the current hippocket.org website now. But we will need to bring in outside expertise for some of the details associated with content management and copyright protection issues. We have dedicated the rest of the budget to that technical assistance. Phase III will require four months.
Schedule
The phases overlap as shown in the figure above. Phase I will begin with the easy tapes. So we will have several shows ready after two months to begin the indexing and cataloguing effort. Phase I and Phase II then proceed in parallel for the majority of the project, which is scheduled to last exactly one year. By the seventh month, we will have a very large body of material ready, and can then begin the website itself. That development is expected to take four months, during which any difficulties with the digitizing and cataloguing of the "problem" tapes can be addressed. In this way, we'll meet our schedule even if an unexpectedly large number of tapes exhibit difficulties.
The End Result
There are more than 30 full-length musical-theatre productions that represent the Simons and Balentine early years. See the video for the top 14 (approximately 2:30 in the Kickstarter video above). When this project has ended, the website will contain as many of these 30 shows as we can locate and catalogue -- one page per show. Each page will hold the musical selections and any video footage that we have been able to recover, as well as photographs and images of scripts, programs and posters.
Above is a wireframe showing one concept for the home page of the website. Design details will be worked out in the early phases with the finished wireframes presented to the web developer for rendering.
The wireframe above shows one concept for user-selection -- in this case, material from the early years prior to the founding of Hip Pocket Theatre. Songs from the Christmas albums, "The Lake Worth Monster", and Casa Playhouse shows contain many of the concepts that seeded the theatre and its early burst of creative output.
The wireframe above shows what one of the show pages might look like. In this case, we have a well-archived show called "Elder Oaks." Along the right, the user can listen to and/or download each song from the show (in mp3 or wav format). In the gray boxes will be promotional materals, a synopsis of the play, and other visual (scanned) material. A scrapbook link and download buttons are placeholders for other materials, which may grow to include scrapbook photos, scripts, cast listings, and a video of the original show performance (if it exists).
There will be some 25 or 30 of these pages, depending on how many shows have survived and what kind of condition the tapes are in. We cannot know for sure the exact page count until Phase I is complete.
I have a detailed project plan showing budgets, timelines, and the technical inventory of all of the tapes. Get in touch with me if you want to see and review it, or if you want to contribute some of your time to assisting in its execution. - Bruce Balentine
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The first and most important part of this project is the digitizing, and there is ample money in the budget to accomplish this. There will be snags -- tapes will break, some material may be lost forever -- but getting it into digital form is the immediate goal. We have lined up several different recovery specialists, and failure by one will lead to hand-offs to another.

The greatest risk is that we experience more problems than expected with the analog tapes. In severe cases, the plan is to try to locate alternative sources. There are thousands of ex-Hip Pocketeers scattered around the world, and one of them may have the cassette of a show that otherwise is taking too many hours to digitize. This Kickstarter project will have the added value of exposing our predicament to all of those performers, stage hands, audience members, and backers that will now have a central focus -- recovering this material -- and we may receive many tapes from people with whom we've long lost touch. In other cases, we'll have to settle for fragmentary pages -- for example a show that has no audio record other than the original piano rehearsal tape recorded by Doug in his home studio. Making these choices will be the dominant activity by those of us immediately responsible for this project, and, of course, we will keep every one of our backers notified as we discover the state and demands of a given show.

Loss of material by having to ship tapes is another obstacle, so we have selected local specialists for most of this work. We also will deliver the tapes (now secure in air-conditioned storage) in small lots to prevent unexpected loss due to theft, fire, incompetence, or other contingencies.

After digitization, there are two major hurdles: first, the material must be annotated, labeled, and organized. Second, the website must be brought up. Much of the former is an act of love (read: no charge) by those who know this material well. But we must pay someone to organize and coordinate the tagging and final labeling, the metadata, cross-referencing, and the uploading. There is money in the budget to accomplish this if we're careful, but the contingency in the event that this task is underestimated is for each of us on this project to chip in the extra that will be required to get everything upload-ready. Luckily, once the material is digitized, this activity will be safer -- we'll be working from copies, and the digital version will not be degrading like the analog tapes are doing.

The final part is the website, and this requires technical skills (i.e., a webmaster) who can develop an effective and accessible website using content-management software. The domain names are already purchased, but there will be server costs (this is a lot of audio and video) and development costs. All of this is budgeted, but unexpected setbacks could delay the work. In such a case, we plan to go to our backers and ask their indulgence as we bring up a subset of the website -- something that they can see and touch and hear -- while we complete the rest in phases.

updates.update_content: Hello, friends and contributors. It's been nine months since my last update and, although many things are going on behind the scenes, it has been a dry spell for the website. I do hope you have been enjoying the many shows and albums that are up now. According to my site dashboard, you are: I receive weekly reports on site visits and other statistics, and I see scores of regular visitors, as well as an average of some 100 or so new visitors each week. There seems to be equal interest in all of the pieces currently posted. For those who haven't been there lately, don't forget the URL:

I'm so sorry for the delay on getting more shows up on this website, they are "in the can" and waiting to go, but I've been working instead on pulling together the materials for this summer's revival of The Lake Worth Monster -- to be performed live at the Hip Pocket Theatre in September and October. This will be the first live production of a Simons & Balentine play in many years, and as "the keeper of the archives," it was up to me to get the material all assembled and ready.
I'm almost finished, and ready to turn it over to Joe Rogers, the Musical Director, and his very able band, Eddie Dunlap, Chris White and Darrin Kobetich; plus the singers: Don Arnett (Cowboy Billy), Patti Littlefield (Belstar and Luna Moon), Grover Coulson (the Monster), and the three backup singers Elysia Ann Worcester, Peggy Bott, and Quentin McGown. James Maynard will once again be Wiley, and will also sing the part of Rue Royal. The show is shaping up nicely.

I just posted Elder Oaks. It was in poor shape, so I had to do quite a bit of editing. There are still some dropped samples ("skipping") but all in all it came out OK. This one brought back memories of the Edinburgh Festival. I hope I got the credits correct in the Lyrics and Script document, let me know if I didn't. Dennis Runge, thinking of you.
Up next, a new batch hot off the press, including Nova's Shady Grove, Cowtown, Paul Revere, and Raggedy Farm. Also coming soon, the 1989 version of Lake Worth Monster.

This show was originally performed at Casino Beach in 1981, and features a tribute to Casino Beach and Casino Ballroom. You can learn more about that history here at this website: http://www.fwtx.com/articles/casino-beach-revitalization
The show also touches on some Lake Worth history based on the fact that land around the lake is leased rather than owned. In a controversial action, the Fort Worth City Council evicted residents from their homes.

The live performance of Hearts of the City, Saturday, September 19, 1981 is now up. This one ate my lunch -- it's a complex live recording that required a lot of editing. There are still some sections of dialogue that change in volume, and I'd love to go back in time and make adjustments to the mix. But it's all there.
This was a big production and a very clever piece of musical theatre. The song lyrics are included, so make it a point to view them as you listen so that you can follow the story and picture the staging. Imagine, especially, the three dance sequences -- the Dallas Ballet (when Ragman and Buck first make it into Dallas); the dream sequence after Sonny has escaped from prison in Huntsville and, while making his way to Fort Worth, has PTSD flashbacks to Vietnam; and the fun at Six Flags Over Texas. These three production numbers are among my favorites that Johnny and Douglas assembled over the years.

Some time has passed since anything new has gone up on the website, sorry about that. I was trying to move quickly, and found myself stymied by the size of the collection -- just making too many mistakes. So I finally decided to set aside the time to copy and label everything more carefully, enter it all into the database, and perform other administrative housekeeping tasks. Not exactly a setback, but it has taken longer than expected. Now I think I have my materials laid out cleanly.
Next up: Hearts of the City, Return of the Creature, the 1989 Lake Worth Monster, Nova's Shady Grove, and an old album by Doug and Jim called, "In Quest of Sylver Dollars." Waiting in the wings is Raggedy Farm and Clown Alley in multi-track format awaiting a mix-down. I set those aside until I could do this clean-up. The older tracks for Cowtown and Paul Revere are a mess, and I'm having to piece those together from fragments. The rest of the shows are lower priority, and will follow these in due time.

The first half of Act I of The Lake Worth Monster -- live broadcast from the studios of KERA national public radio in Dallas in 1982 -- is now up on the site. I have also written a blog about the piece.
I have almost finished editing the rest of the show, and will have it up before too long. Also, volunteers are starting to come forward to offer their help, so I am excited that we will soon start seeing photos, lyrics and scripts.

Hello everyone.
The site has two new shows, "Old Mother West Wind" (which I'm sure you all agree is a real charmer) and a very special posting, the original rehearsal tape for "The Lake Worth Monster" (LWM). I'll be adding some notes and comments on this -- the very first Simons and Balentine collaboration. I'm also nearly finished editing the KERA Blockbuster version of LWM from 1983, as well as the last revival performance of LWM at the Hip Pocket Theatre in 1989.

The campaign continues! New rewards! Announcing our website: IndieVanGameJam.com!
The series is about asking a question. Every episode is a question about game design that we think the studio we’re visiting is trying to answer. As we travel to their studio in the Indie Van, we explore the answer to that question ourselves in the form of a game jam.
A Sample Episode
For example, say we travel to BioWare (not an Indie, but a great example!), they usually make games that involve branched storytelling and choices. The question for them might be ‘is truly consequential branched storytelling actually possible in video games?’ This is a question many folks have asked about game design over the years. Once we have The Question that is right for the studio, we hop in the Indie Van and game jam along the way, trying our hardest to answer the question ourselves. When we arrive at the studio, we interview the developers and ask them The Question – then we show them the current state of our game jam and see what insights they have. Now, armed with the sage wisdom of the masters, we finish the game jam in the van on the way home and release it with the episode as a digital download. (More on that later.) 
Check out a video teaser for what kind of talk we talk with someone like Stoic!
A Series?
Yes, indeed! We want to film an 8 episode series. That means we want to create 8 web episodes, featuring 8 indie developers, spanning 8 different cities, and delivering 8 small game jam games which could range from totally awesome to total trainwreck! These games will be made available for download at the same time the episode airs, so you can join us on the adventure.
The series is about the DIY spirit – start working now! Do it yourself! Just go find the people who are experts and ask them how they got there! You don’t need to wait to be discovered, go out and get it! The series is about travel! We wander through the world seeking out our heroes and trying to meet them at eye level! We explore the world and turn up pockets of awesomeness all over the place! We get travel-weary and car-crazy and grumpy and eat weird local food! We try to become a part of these places we’re visiting, like travelers, not tourists! The series is about Zeb and Chad and our dumb sense of humor! Our own weird perspectives on games and what we think is awesome about them! Our dumb jokes! About how our personalities are both similar and different and the celebration of that!
Games!

Binary Solo is a two-man indie studio formed by Chad Stewart and Zeb West in Austin, TX. Our mission is simple: Make the games that we would want to play, and play the games that we would want to make. 
Chad and Zeb met while working on Star Wars: The Old Republic at BioWare Austin and bonded over a shared desire to charge into the vibrant indie scene which has erupted in North America. With new tools, markets and funding channels available to the masses, and a rebellious dissatisfaction with the increasingly bland games being turned out by large publishers, now is the time to make the game you dreamed about. Chad is programming and president, Zeb is production and design. Together they are on a crusade to stamp out the jive and bring in the love. 
The Indie game scene is so vibrant right now, with the tools for development and distribution being democratized – readily available and in the hands of the people! That’s causing some outrageous games to come out as a result of a revolution – shaking up the games that large publishers have been delivering to gamers, and giving rise to vibrant, experimental new flavors and genres, answering an outcry for something new. We thought it would be fun to get right inside this bustling scene, and show what the indie developers are doing – how they’re going about things differently, how that ‘do it yourself’ indie spirit is spawning innovation and creativity. Seeing how a small pack of passionate developers can turn out something better and more interesting than armies of corporate developers who might be so compartmentalized and disenfranchised that they've lost the fire for the games they’re making!
Video games are such a young industry it’s easy to forget that the development structure and a publishing model is still being defined! What happens when you put the tools of production in the hands of smart, savvy, hungry creatives who care more about making the games they want, than making the games they think would sell like a blockbuster?  
This series will be vital to the next generation of gamers. They will get a window into the pioneers on the indie front. They’ll be inspired by that ‘do it yourself’ spirit and hopefully make the connection that everything they need is in front of them. That young developer or armchair designer will get an over-the-shoulder view of the back-yard wrestling of game development: The developers who took that scary leap outside the studio/publisher system in order to follow their passion.
This tour goes across the country (and maybe across the maple curtain into Canadian!) Starting in Austin, TX; we will be traveling around North America seeking out independent developers big and small. Who will this include?

John Watson, Arnie Jorgenson, and Alex Thomas are the makers of the kickstarter-backed, gorgeous, and epic turn-based strategy game The Banner Saga. In the Spring of 2013, they released Banner Saga: Factions, and are currently working day and night to finish the single player version.

The Indie Game Collective is a unique group of studios and individual developers located in a single co-working space in Boston. They collaborate and help each other, a group of indies toiling together. The Collective includes: Ichiro Lambe and Rohit Shenoy (Dejobaan Games),  David W. Evans (Hybrid Mind Studios), Erik Asmussen (82 Apps) , Michael Carriere (ZapDot), Trevor Stricker (Disco Pixel), and more.

This is tricky, because most people I know are not in Canada. But if you are, or if you go there, I'll make sure there's a ticket for you.

What is it?
In one wild hour, award-winning solo performer Zeb L. West smashes together Moby Dick and Don Quixote using puppets, masks, old timey stagecraft, physical comedy, sea shanties, and shameless antics.
Late last year, Zeb won the Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals international touring lottery, automatically enrolling him in seven different Fringe Festivals all across Canada.  This summer, Zeb takes the show on the road, spanning most of Canada, and hitting festivals from Ottawa to Victoria.  You can follow along with his progress here!
But what's it about?
Set deep in the belly of a whale, the show is about that rock bottom moment after a tragedy (in this case, Jonah's broken heart) when you decide how you're going to think, and how you're going to treat yourself. Jonah has been swallowed and driven mad by only having two books to read - Don Quixote and Moby Dick. He thinks the whole theater has been swallowed too and starts to act out the books using puppets and masks fashioned from flotsam.
Who's Zeb?
Zeb West studied physical theater, clown and mask-making at the Dell'Arte School in California, and is a member of Austin's Trouble Puppet Theater Company and Brooklyn's Alphabet Arts.
Last Summer I took off in the car and headed up to Canada to check out the Fringe festivals and I built a puppet show in the car that I street performed as a way to contribute some fringe art and meet nice people. I've been doing theater in San Francisco, New York, Philadelphia and Austin for the past 15 or so years and touring nationally performing with masks and puppets.

Where will your money go?
This trip is a labor of love, but who ever said love is free? I've made a detailed budget that includes everything from props and costumes to handbills to gas for the car.
This whole adventure is about doing more with less. How much fun and joy I can put into a simple show? How many shirts do I need for a two month road trip? And how can I do it all on the cheap?
I'm asking only for what the show needs, down to the dollar. That's why the funding goal is so specific.
It's always nice to receive mail from an actual human!
What's in it for you?
I thought a lot about what rewards would give you a chance to stay connected to this far-flung adventure -- and also give me a chance to stay connected to you. Postcards and videos from the road. Tickets to the shows if you're there in Canada. A replica of the great Don Quixote mask I made. I wanted to give you guys some sweet choices.
